importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the current status and ongoing development of the Reefline project in Miami Beach.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Reefline project is expected to take at least a decade to complete, with full realization anticipated by around 2035.

keyTakeAways: Reefline is a 7-mile-long artificial reef project off Miami Beach designed to restore a historically lost coral reef habitat.
The project combines marine science and art, using underwater sculptures made from marine-grade concrete to serve as coral-growing platforms.
Colin Foord, a coral researcher and founder of Coral Morphologic, is responsible for cultivating and transplanting over 2,000 soft coral specimens that will grow on the reef.
Artistic director Ximena Caminos, originally from Argentina, is a cultural placemaker who has used art to revitalize communities in Buenos Aires and Miami Beach.
The project includes 22 concrete cars arranged in a traffic jam formation, which act as coral habitats and will be gradually covered by growing corals.
The project is funded by a $5 million city bond and seeks an additional $6 million through fundraising to launch its first phase.
The Reefline project is expected to revive a former coral reef ecosystem that was lost to sand replenishment in the 1970s.
The project includes an onshore marine learning center to educate the public about endangered coral reefs and may one day feature a constellation of 57 giant starfish as a city symbol.
The reef will be accessible to swimmers in about 15 to 20 feet of water, 700 feet off Miami Beach, without requiring a boat.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Miami Beach is launching the Reefline project, a 7-mile-long artificial reef that combines marine science and art to restore a historically lost coral reef ecosystem. Led by coral expert Colin Foord and artistic director Ximena Caminos, the project features underwater sculptures—such as 22 concrete cars—designed to host resilient soft corals that will grow over time, transforming the structures into vibrant, living reefs. The initiative, funded by a $5 million city bond and seeking an additional $6 million, aims to revitalize marine biodiversity, promote ecotourism, and provide public access to underwater environments. The reef will be accessible to swimmers in just 15 to 20 feet of water, 700 feet off the beach, and includes an onshore education center to teach about coral reef conservation. The project reflects a broader mission of cultural placemaking, drawing from Ximena Caminos' experience in urban revitalization in Buenos Aires, and could one day feature 57 giant starfish as a symbol of Miami Beach’s ecological rebirth.
title: Miami Beach puts the art in offshore artificial reef
